unnormalised: Ah, the Indian Railways! A saga in steel, a ballet of baggage, and a comedy in compartments. For the uninitiated, boarding an Indian train is akin to entering a parallel universe where time moves at its own (glacial) pace and personal space is a myth perpetuated by Hollywood. If you're planning a rail adventure across Bharat, brace yourself and remember: laughter is the best chai!

If you are planning a rail adventure across Bharat, brace yourself and remember: laughter is the best chai!

unnormalised: First, the booking. Attempting to secure a ticket on IRCTC is a test of patience, internet speed, and karmic balance. You’re battling millions of other Indians, all equally desperate to reach their destinations. Be prepared for server crashes, CAPTCHA challenges that would stump Einstein, and the sinking realization that your 'waitlisted' ticket has a better chance of winning the lottery than confirming. Pro tip: Book well in advance. Like, maybe for Diwali 2025, if you're travelling during peak season.

Be prepared for server crashes, C-A-P-T-C-H-A challenges that would stump Einstein, and the sinking realization that your 'waitlisted' ticket has a better chance of winning the lottery than confirming. Pro tip: Book well in advance. Like, maybe for Diwali two thousand and twenty five, if you are travelling during peak season.

unnormalised: Then comes the station experience. Imagine a mela, a cattle market, and a rock concert all rolled into one chaotic symphony. Navigating the platform is an art. Dodge rogue trolleys laden with enough luggage to rival a small cargo ship, sidestep families picnicking on the floor, and ignore the persistent calls of "chai, garam chai!" Remember, the only constant is change, and that includes platform numbers announced 5 minutes before departure.

unnormalised: The train itself is a microcosm of India. Inside, you’ll find a cross-section of society: students cramming for exams, families embarking on pilgrimages, and business folk glued to their phones. Be prepared to share your space – and your snacks. Uncle Sharma WILL offer you a samosa, even if you've just devoured a whole plate of pani puri. Politely decline at your own peril.

unnormalised: The food situation is another source of amusement. Railway catering is a culinary adventure. The “veg biryani” might contain mysterious vegetables you've never seen before, and the "cutlet" might resemble a fossilized hockey puck. Embrace the uncertainty, or pack your own parathas. Vendor calls are a part of the experience though, and "aloo tikki... garam garam!" is always something to smile about.

unnormalised: Toilets? Ah, yes, the legendary Indian Railways toilets. Let's just say they’re an experience best described as "character-building." Pack hand sanitizer, wet wipes, and a healthy dose of stoicism. And maybe a nose clip, just in case. Try to use the loo at bigger stations, your chances of relative cleanliness increase tenfold.

unnormalised: Delays are as predictable as the sunrise. The train will inevitably be "running late" by a few hours. Use this time wisely. Make new friends, practice your Hindi, or simply contemplate the meaning of life while staring out the window at the passing countryside. Remember, the journey is the destination, or at least that’s what you tell yourself when you’re stuck in the middle of nowhere at 3:00 AM.

unnormalised: But amidst all the chaos and the occasional discomfort, there’s a certain magic to travelling by Indian Railways. It's a chance to see the real India, to connect with people from all walks of life, and to create memories that will last a lifetime. So, grab your ticket, pack your sense of humor, and hop on board. Just don’t forget the hand sanitizer. And try to prepone your arrival, since it's likely the train will not be on time!
